title: Placer (geography)
text:
Placer ( or "pracel") is a term used by <a href="Portuguese%20discoveries">Portuguese</a> and <a href="list%20of%20conquistadors">Spanish</a> navigators and cartographers to refer to a certain kind of submerged <a href="ocean%20bank">bank</a> or <a href="reef">reef</a>. Commonly the bottom of such a reef is <a href="sand">sand</a>y, but there are some where the bottom is <a href="mud">mud</a>dy or <a href="stone">stone</a>y. Although most reefs designated as placer are flat and shallow, exceptionally there are some that do not share those characteristics and are known as "placer acantilado". A placer usually provides an <a href="anchorage%20%28maritime%29">anchorage</a> for seagoing vessels.
Etymology.
Spanish navigator and explorer <a href="Pedro%20Sarmiento%20de%20Gamboa">Pedro Sarmiento de Gamboa</a> commented that "placer" likely originated as a term derived from <a href="placer%20mining">placer mining</a> in the <a href="Antilles">Antilles</a>, where <a href="pearl%20fishing">pearl fishing</a> was done mostly on shallow sandy reefs, which were compared to the sandy grounds in rivers where gold nuggets were found. 
Since the word "Placer" in Spanish means 'pleasure', according to 16th century scientist <a href="Juan%20P%C3%A9rez%20de%20Moya">Juan Pérez de Moya</a> a placer is every dangerous submerged shallow bank. Moya claims that the landforms that received this denomination did so in an ironical manner, for it would be everything but a pleasure to navigate those treacherous waters under the constant risk of running aground.
However, other navigators contradict Moya by claiming that such a shallow ground would provide mariners with a much welcome anchorage after a long open sea journey, for in some "placeres" the waters are not as rough as in the open seas.
Use of the term.
The term appears in Spanish <a href="nautical%20chart">nautical chart</a>s as "placer", although Pedro Sarmiento de Gamboa writes it as "placel".
The <a href="Portuguese%20language">Portuguese language</a> equivalent and derived term is "pracel" or "parcel". In present times some of the geographical names used by the Spanish cartographers, such as "Placer de los Colorados," "Placer de los Estudios," "Placer de Playa Grande," "Placer de Montechristi," "Placer de Quatro Cayos", "Placer de la Gallega", "Placer de las Tortugas" and "Placer de los Siete Hermanos" have become obsolete or have been superseded by English terms. Still, many other "placeres" mentioned in 19th-century Spanish Navigation Instruction Manuals were not even named. Not all "placeres" are in the open sea; the "Isla Cangrejos" in the <a href="Orinoco%20Delta">Orinoco Delta</a> was described as having a "placer" that stretched from its NE point composed of ground-coffee coloured hard sand.
